pyfoma.private package

Submodules

pyfoma.private.partition_refinement module

class pyfoma.private.partition_refinement.PartitionRefinement(S)[source]

Bases: object

Basic partition refinement using dicts. A pared down version of D. Eppstein’s implementation. https://www.ics.uci.edu/~eppstein/PADS/PartitionRefinement.py

__init__(S)[source]

Create a new partition refinement data structure for the given items. Initially, all items belong to the same subset.

astuples()[source]

Get current partitioning and convert to set of tuples.

refine(S)[source]

Refine each set A in the partition to the two sets A & S, A - S. Return a list of pairs (A & S, A - S) for each changed set. Within each pair, A & S will be a newly created set, while A - S will be a modified version of an existing set in the partition. Not a generator because we need to perform the partition even if the caller doesn’t iterate through the results.

pyfoma.private.regexparse module

class pyfoma.private.regexparse.RegexParse(regularexpression, defined, functions)[source]

Bases: object

__init__(regularexpression, defined, functions)[source]

Tokenize, parse, and compile regex into FST. ‘I define UNIX as 30 definitions of regular expressions living under one roof.’ - Don Knuth, Digital Typography, ch. 33, p. 649 (1999)

builtins = {'determinize': <function determinized>, 'ignore': <function ignore>, 'input': <function RegexParse.<lambda>>, 'invert': <function inverted>, 'minimize': <function minimized>, 'output': <function RegexParse.<lambda>>, 'project': <function RegexParse.<lambda>>, 'restrict': <function context_restricted>, 'reverse': <function reversed>, 'rewrite': <function rewritten>}
character_class_parse(charclass)[source]

Parse a character class into range pairs, e.g. ‘a-zA’ => [(97,122), (65,65)]. ‘Writing clear and unambiguous specifications for character classes is tough, and implementing them perfectly is worse, requiring a lot of tedious and uninstructive coding.’ -Brian Kernighan (in “Beautiful Code”, 2007).

compile() → FST[source]

Put it all together! ‘If you lie to the compiler, it will have its revenge.’ — Henry Spencer.

operands = {'ANY', 'CHAR_CLASS', 'EPSILON', 'SYMBOL', 'VARIABLE'}
operators = {'COMMA', 'COMPLEMENT', 'COMPOSE', 'CONCAT', 'CONTEXT', 'CP', 'CPOPTIONAL', 'FUNC', 'INTERSECTION', 'MINUS', 'OPTIONAL', 'PAIRUP', 'PARAM', 'PLUS', 'RANGE', 'STAR', 'UNION', 'WEIGHT'}
parse() → list[source]

Attention! Those who don’t speak reverse Polish will be shunted! ‘Simplicity is a great virtue but it requires hard work to achieve it and education to appreciate it. And to make matters worse: complexity sells better.’ - E. Dijkstra

precedence = {'COMMA': 1, 'COMPLEMENT': 7, 'COMPOSE': 3, 'CONCAT': 6, 'CONTEXT': 1, 'CP': 10, 'CPOPTIONAL': 10, 'FUNC': 11, 'INTERSECTION': 5, 'MINUS': 5, 'OPTIONAL': 9, 'PAIRUP': 2, 'PARAM': 1, 'PLUS': 9, 'RANGE': 9, 'STAR': 9, 'UNION': 5, 'WEIGHT': 9}
shortops = {'&': 'INTERSECTION', '(': 'LPAREN', ')': 'RPAREN', '*': 'STAR', '+': 'PLUS', ',': 'COMMA', '-': 'MINUS', '/': 'CONTEXT', ':': 'CP', ':?': 'CPOPTIONAL', '?': 'OPTIONAL', '@': 'COMPOSE', '_': 'PAIRUP', '|': 'UNION', '~': 'COMPLEMENT'}
tokenize() → list[source]

Token, token, token, though the stream is broken… ride ‘em in, tokenize!

unarypost = {'OPTIONAL', 'PLUS', 'RANGE', 'STAR', 'WEIGHT'}
unarypre = {'COMPLEMENT'}
